messages.text: Libjulia in master and release-1.6 is broken on macOS for me. AFAICT since the split into libjulia and libjulia-intern (reexported symbols in libjulia are missing leading underscores). See <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/38925|https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/38925> -- IMHO a release blocker?

messages.text: Is the 1.5 branch still accepting direct PRs or will there be no more releases on the branch? (I am wondering becase GCC has again changed header include chains in GCC 11, so LLVM <12 needs a patch to build on GCC 11 now).

elements.text: Is the 1.5 branch still accepting direct PRs or will there be no more releases on the branch? (I am wondering becase GCC has again changed header include chains in GCC 11, so LLVM <12 needs a patch to build on GCC 11 now).

messages.text: You can always make a PR.  The obstacles are getting someone to review it, and getting it to pass CI.  1.5 should be easy since it’s pretty recent.  You can ping me for a review.  There may not be another release, but if you need to, you can always download the source tarball for that commit directly.

elements.text: You can always make a PR.  The obstacles are getting someone to review it, and getting it to pass CI.  1.5 should be easy since it’s pretty recent.  You can ping me for a review.  There may not be another release, but if you need to, you can always download the source tarball for that commit directly.

messages.text: Thanks, I think I might put together the PR once <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/39106> is reviewed. There is also another change that is needed for GCC11 on 1.5, so putting it all into a single commit will help packagers with any backporting.

messages.text: Yeah, it's mostly to create a branch against release-1.5, put all the backported commits onto it, run benchmarks and pkg eval, look into the logs of those, merge when it looks fine, make a new PR that bumps the version. Merge it. Ping Alex to update website etc.

elements.text: Yeah, it's mostly to create a branch against release-1.5, put all the backported commits onto it, run benchmarks and pkg eval, look into the logs of those, merge when it looks fine, make a new PR that bumps the version. Merge it. Ping Alex to update website etc.

messages.text: unfortunately <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/38938> was not fully backported to release-1.6 and as a consequence <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/38925> is not really fixed. I added a comment their to explain what is missing, but I am concerned this might be missed on closed PRs/issues, so I am mentioning it here. Perhaps someone can reopen the issue and/or backport the missing commit? Or should I open a PR against the release-1.6 branch with the missing commit? How do you prefer it?

messages.text: Is there a formal process how a PR goes from being approved to being actually merged? <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/39065> was approved 17 days ago... one test keeps failing, but that's the test which keeps failing for almost all PRs all the time. But perhaps that's the blocker?

elements.text: Is there a formal process how a PR goes from being approved to being actually merged?
was approved 17 days ago... one test keeps failing, but that's the test which keeps failing for almost all PRs all the time. But perhaps that's the blocker?

messages.text: We are planning on formalizing the process for PRs made from forks: <https://github.com/JuliaLang/pull-request-state-machine|https://github.com/JuliaLang/pull-request-state-machine>

elements.text: We are planning on formalizing the process for PRs made from forks:
https://github.com/JuliaLang/pull-request-state-machine

messages.text: Based on this state machine specification: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/suggestion-to-slightly-improve-julia-development/50916/82|https://discourse.julialang.org/t/suggestion-to-slightly-improve-julia-development/50916/82>

attachments.title: Suggestion to slightly improve Julia development
attachments.text: One observation I have here is that it’s quite easy for PRs to “get lost in the shuffle”. If someone doesn’t happen to review it and give necessary feedback or if the author forgets about it for a while, it’s very easy for it to fall by the wayside. A way to address this would be to have a state machine for PRs that is partially automated and partially manual with clear roles. Here’s my attempt to write down such a state machine. This only covers PRs from non-committers since committers can shep...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Suggestion to slightly improve Julia development

elements.text: Based on this state machine specification:
https://discourse.julialang.org/t/suggestion-to-slightly-improve-julia-development/50916/82

messages.text: Chris and I are both pretty busy at the moment, but if people want to work on the state machine and make pull requests to <https://github.com/JuliaLang/pull-request-state-machine|https://github.com/JuliaLang/pull-request-state-machine>, I'm happy to review and merge.

messages.text: another PR of mine that should be fine is <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/39073> but I've by now rebased it multiple times to rerun tests, and every time one fails -- same as it was with <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/39065> i.e. I am sure it's not caused by my changes. What should I do? Just keep re-running all tests until by luck it manages to pass them all?
